title: Cyclone Dana Batters Odisha and South Bengal
news:
Cyclone Dana, a severe cyclonic storm, made landfall on the Odisha coast early Friday morning, October 25, 2024, bringing heavy rain and gusty winds to the region.  The storm's rear sector is also impacting southern West Bengal.

The Indian Meteorological Department (IMD) reported that the storm was centered over north coastal Odisha, moving west-northwestwards across the region. The landfall process is expected to continue for a few more hours before the storm weakens into a cyclonic storm later today.

The impact of the cyclone is already being felt in the affected areas. Waterlogging has been reported in Mandarmani, Purba Medinipur, and Gosaba, South 24 Parganas, causing distress for residents. 

In preparation for the storm, the Odisha and West Bengal governments evacuated over 2.5 lakh people from low-lying areas. The state of West Bengal deployed disaster management and National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) personnel to the coastal regions.

Due to the heavy winds and rain, Kolkata's Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose International Airport suspended operations from Thursday evening until Friday morning.  Train services in the region have also been severely affected, with South Eastern Railway canceling over 170 trains and Eastern Railway suspending suburban services. 

Kolkata Port authorities halted ship movements as a precautionary measure.

Authorities remain on high alert as the full extent of the damage caused by Cyclone Dana continues to unfold.

title: Terrorist Attack in Baramulla, J&K: Army Operation Underway
news:
An ongoing military operation is underway in Baramulla, Jammu and Kashmir, following a terrorist attack on Thursday evening. The attack resulted in the deaths of two Indian Army soldiers and two civilian porters.  One soldier and one porter remain injured and are currently receiving medical treatment.

The incident occurred when terrorists ambushed a military vehicle in the Butapathri area.  A subsequent update from the Chinar Corps confirmed the ongoing nature of the operation. 

This follows another terrorist incident on October 24th where a laborer was shot and injured in the Batgund Tral area of Pulwama district. 

The escalation of violence comes after a separate incident on October 20th where a doctor and six construction workers were killed in a terrorist attack on a tunnel construction site near Ganderbal district.

title: Visakhapatnam Police Suspend Four for Extortion
news:

Prasad, Sheikh Naseeruddin, R. Venkata Trinadh, and Ch. Siva Ganesh, were accused of extorting money from drivers during a drunken driving check on the Beach Road on October 17.

title: ITC Q2 Results: Mixed Bag for the Conglomerate
news:
ITC's Q2 results showed a mixed bag for the Indian conglomerate, with strong revenue growth but pressure on margins. Revenue increased by 16.8% year-on-year, surpassing analyst expectations due to strong performance in the agri business. Cigarette volumes grew in line with projections, driven by portfolio and market initiatives.

However, FMCG "Others" Ebitda fell due to inflationary pressures and weak performance in the notebooks business, struggling against local competitors and lower paper prices. The paper segment also saw muted growth due to cheap Chinese imports. 

Analysts remain optimistic about ITC's long-term prospects, citing its strong competitive position and size. Antique Stock Broking maintained a "Buy" recommendation with a target price of Rs 557, while Emkay Global maintained an "Add" rating with a target price of Rs 520, acknowledging near-term margin challenges. Other analysts, including Citi, Nomura, and Morgan Stanley, also hold positive views on ITC. 

Despite the mixed results, ITC's Q2 performance showcased its resilience in a challenging market. The company's diversified portfolio and strong brand portfolio position it for continued growth, but it will need to address margin pressures effectively to achieve its full potential.

title: AI is Saving Lives: LeCun Highlights Healthcare and Transportation Advancements
news:
Meta's Chief AI Scientist, Yann LeCun, recently outlined the life-saving potential of AI in healthcare and transportation.  He showcased how AI technologies are actively improving lives through advancements in areas like:

**Transportation:** AI-powered systems like automatic emergency braking are reducing frontal collisions by 40%. This technology, now mandatory in the EU, uses cameras to detect obstacles and automatically brakes the car, preventing accidents. 

**Healthcare:**  AI is revolutionizing medical image analysis, aiding doctors in detecting early signs of diseases.  AI systems analyze mammograms, flagging non-suspicious cases, allowing radiologists to focus on potentially problematic images.  LeCun also highlighted Meta's FastMRI project, which utilizes AI to significantly reduce the time needed for MRI scans, leading to earlier detection of tumors and improved patient outcomes. 

LeCun emphasizes that AI is not replacing doctors, but rather serving as a powerful tool to improve diagnostic accuracy and efficiency, ultimately leading to better patient outcomes.  The transformative power of AI, he asserts, is already saving lives and improving the quality of life for millions worldwide.

title: Cyient Shares Rise on Strong Q2 Earnings and Interim Dividend

title: Ratan Tata's Fortune: Foundation to Manage Legacy, Staff and Loyal Companion Benefit
news:
The late Ratan Tata's substantial fortune, estimated at ₹10,000 crore, will be managed by the Ratan Tata Endowment Foundation (RTEF), established in 2022. This foundation, focused on social welfare, will receive Tata's stake in Tata Sons and other group companies, ensuring his philanthropic legacy continues. 

Tata Sons chairman N Chandrasekaran is expected to lead the foundation, carrying on Tata's vision for social good. RTEF has already made strategic investments, such as in Tata Technologies and Tata Digital. 

Tata's will also provides for close family members and his loyal staff, including his cook and butler, who served him for decades. Shantanu Naidu, Tata's executive assistant, is also a beneficiary; his personal loan was forgiven and Tata relinquished his stake in Naidu's venture, highlighting their close relationship.

In a unique gesture for India, Tata ensured lifelong care for his German shepherd, Tito, with provisions guaranteeing "unlimited" care. 

Tata's personal estate, including a collection of luxury cars, his Alibaug bungalow, and Mumbai residence, will be handled through the RTEF. While the details are still being finalized, it's clear that Tata's fortune will continue to benefit society through his foundation.

title: Media is a Bridge Between Government and People, Says Guntur MLA
news:

title: Congress MLC Jeevan Reddy Criticizes Defections, Expresses Concern Over Party Loyalty
news:

In a letter addressed to AICC president Mallikarjun Kharge, Reddy expressed deep concern over the impact of these defections, particularly highlighting the recent murder of his close associate and senior Congress leader Maru Ganga Reddy. The murder, allegedly committed by Bathini Santosh, who defected to the Congress alongside BRS MLA Sanjay Kumar in Jagtial, has shaken the Congress cadre in the region. 

Reddy further criticized the role of former Speaker and BRS MLA Pocharam Srinivas Reddy in facilitating these defections, accusing him of orchestrating similar defections in the previous term. title: OpenAI Safety Researcher Departs, Citing Concerns over AGI Readiness
news:
Miles Brundage, OpenAI's senior advisor for artificial general intelligence (AGI) readiness, has resigned, highlighting a growing divide within the company over its approach to AGI. In his farewell statement, Brundage expressed concern that neither OpenAI nor the world is prepared for the arrival of AGI. 

Brundage, who spent six years developing OpenAI's safety frameworks, asserts that the company's recent shift towards commercialization and monetized applications has diluted its original focus on safe AGI development. This departure follows a series of exits from OpenAI's safety team, including researcher Jan Leike and co-founder Ilya Sutskever, who both raised concerns about the company's prioritization of products over safety.

Brundage's concerns echo a broader debate within the AI community about the ethical implications of AGI. While some researchers remain committed to advancing AI for societal benefit, others are increasingly critical of the rapid commercialization of the technology and its potential for unintended consequences. 

Brundage plans to pursue independent research on AI governance, hoping to foster open dialogue on the topic without corporate influence as the field moves closer to AGI.

title: Faith and Frenzy: The Banni Festival at Devaragattu Temple
news:
The annual Banni Festival in Devaragattu, a village on the Andhra Pradesh-Karnataka border, is a unique blend of religious fervor and chaotic ritual. Held during the Dasara festivities, the festival culminates in the “Banni Jaitra Yatra” procession, where villagers wielding sticks and carrying torches escort the deities of Mala Malleswara Swamy and his consort through the village.  This procession, though deeply ingrained in tradition, has also been marked by violence and bloodshed, with injuries and even fatalities occurring in recent years.

The stick-fighting, known as “Karrala Samaram”, is believed to be a symbolic reenactment of Lord Shiva’s victory over demons. Some devotees believe participating in the fight brings good luck, attributing any injuries received as blessings from the deity. However, the actual practice has become increasingly violent, with villagers often clashing with each other, injuring devotees in the process.

Despite the widespread evidence of violence, no police cases have been filed, and locals deny the existence of any organized fight for control of the deities. The festival's priest maintains that the violence is an exaggeration, claiming that the stick fighting is simply a part of the procession and not an intentional act of aggression.

This year, despite the continued presence of the controversial stick-fighting, there were no reported deaths. This is attributed to the efforts of the police and district administration, who deployed drones and CCTV surveillance to monitor the festival and intervened to minimize violence.  Despite these efforts, many participants still sustained injuries, demonstrating the need for a change in the ritual's execution.

Efforts to educate villagers and encourage the use of safer alternatives, such as plastic sticks, have not yielded substantial results. The police remain hopeful that with time and ongoing efforts, the festival will become more peaceful, allowing devotees to celebrate their faith without the risk of injury or death.

title: Trudeau to Lead Liberals into Next Election Despite Calls to Step Down
news:
Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has announced his intention to lead the Liberal Party into the next federal election, despite calls from some party members for him to step down.  This decision comes after a meeting with his Liberal MPs, where over 20 lawmakers expressed their desire for a leadership change. 

Trudeau's decision has sparked controversy, as he faces mounting pressure due to recent electoral losses and public dissatisfaction with his handling of key issues such as the rising cost of living. The Liberals recently lost special elections in two Toronto and Montreal districts, raising concerns about his leadership and potentially impacting their chances in the upcoming election.

While Trudeau has received support from the majority of his Cabinet Ministers, some MPs remain unconvinced. Sean Casey, one of the MPs who signed the letter calling for Trudeau's resignation, expressed disappointment but accepted the decision, focusing his efforts on winning his own seat.

The upcoming election is scheduled between this fall and next October, with the Liberals requiring the support of at least one other major party to form a government. The Bloc Québécois, the Conservative Party, and the New Democratic Party are all poised to challenge the Liberal Party's hold on power.

Despite facing criticism, Trudeau remains confident in his leadership. He has emphasized that he will continue to lead the party into the next election, citing his ability to address key concerns and build a better future for Canada. The coming months will prove crucial in determining whether Trudeau's gamble will pay off and see him return as Prime Minister.

title: Bengaluru's Thirst Quenched, But at What Cost?
news:
The long-awaited Cauvery V Stage project, bringing piped water to 110 villages surrounding Bengaluru, has finally been commissioned.  This project, costing ₹4,600 crore, promises to alleviate the water woes of these rapidly urbanized areas, which have been reliant on expensive tankers and borewells.

The BWSSB aims to provide connections to at least 4 lakh households, increasing their revenue to ₹140 crore per month. However, the project is facing teething problems:

* **Distribution Network:** While the main pipelines are laid, distribution channels are not yet complete in some areas, leading to delays in connections.
* **High Costs:** Apartment communities are complaining about high connection fees, with some estimating costs exceeding ₹1 lakh per flat.  The BWSSB's current system charges the entire apartment as one connection, making it financially prohibitive for many.
* **Overreliance on Cauvery:** The project, coupled with the planned Cauvery VI Stage, will increase Bengaluru's water consumption to 35 tmcft annually, exceeding the allocated 23 tmcft for the city. This raises concerns from farmers who argue that Bengaluru's water needs are prioritized over agricultural needs.

These concerns highlight the need for sustainable water management strategies in Bengaluru. While the Cauvery V Stage project offers immediate relief, it reinforces the city's dependence on a single water source. Experts call for:

* **Judicious Water Use:**  Incentivizing water conservation measures and implementing dual pricing models to make water usage more equitable.
* **Alternative Sources:**  Prioritizing rainwater harvesting, watershed management, and treated wastewater for non-potable uses.

The success of the Cauvery V Stage project will ultimately depend on addressing these concerns and moving towards a more sustainable water future for Bengaluru.

title: Cyclone Dana Makes Landfall on Odisha Coast, IMD Issues Warnings
news:
Cyclone Dana began its landfall on the Odisha coast on Thursday night, bringing with it high winds and heavy rainfall. The Indian Meteorological Department (IMD) issued severe weather warnings, stating that the landfall process would continue until Friday morning.

The coastal districts of Bhadrak, Kendrapara, Balasore, and Jagatsinghpur experienced wind speeds reaching 100-110 kmph, accompanied by intense rainfall. While reports of uprooted trees were received, no major damage or casualties have been reported so far.

The IMD forecasts wind speeds to reach 120 kmph at the storm's center and a tidal surge of up to two meters above the astronomical height in the affected districts. The landfall process is expected to last for about four to five hours.

Despite the storm's intensity, the Odisha government had proactively evacuated around 5.84 lakh people from high-risk areas in coastal districts.  The IMD further predicts that the storm will gradually weaken on Friday as it moves further inland, bringing heavy rainfall to most of Odisha. 

The IMD has issued warnings for gale-force winds and heavy rainfall, urging residents to remain vigilant and follow safety guidelines.

title: Supreme Court Rejects NGO Plea on Punitive Demolitions
news:
The Supreme Court of India has dismissed a plea by the National Federation of Indian Women (NFIW) challenging punitive demolitions carried out by states like Uttar Pradesh, Uttarakhand, and Rajasthan.  The court deemed the NGO a third party with no direct or indirect stake in the demolitions.

A three-judge bench led by Justice B.R. Gavai emphasized that those directly affected by the demolitions should approach the court. "We do not want to open a Pandora’s box by entertaining this at the instance of a third party," Justice Gavai said.

The court had previously issued a stay order in September against such demolitions, recognizing them as a form of "bulldozer justice" and emphasizing that authorities cannot bulldoze the law. While the court acknowledged the stay order's applicability to the current case, it maintained its position that only those directly impacted by the demolitions have standing to bring the case before the court.

The NFIW argued that the stay order should apply to the demolitions in question, and that many affected individuals were unable to access legal recourse due to imprisonment or displacement. Justice Gavai refuted this, suggesting that family members or even concerned neighbors could act on behalf of those affected.

The court's decision highlights its commitment to ensuring a fair and impartial legal process in addressing these demolitions. While acknowledging the concerns raised by the NFIW, the court has maintained its position that those directly impacted by the actions must be the ones to seek legal redress.

title: Jharkhand Election: A Battle for the Women's Vote
news:
As Jharkhand prepares for its two-phase Assembly election next month, women have emerged as a key voting bloc. The ruling JMM-led coalition and the Opposition BJP are vying for their support, showering promises of financial assistance. This strategy has been effective in other states, with parties like the BJP employing similar tactics in Madhya Pradesh and Maharashtra.

The JMM government's Mukhyamantri Maiya Samman Yojana (MMSY) provides ₹1,000 per month to women aged 18-50. The BJP, in response, has launched its Gogo Didi Yojana, offering ₹2,100 per month. The JMM has since increased the MMSY payment to ₹2,500, further escalating the competition for women's votes. 

While both parties use this financial assistance as a key campaign tool, women in Jharkhand appear less concerned with the political maneuvering and more focused on the direct benefits.  Many beneficiaries, like Sukhiya Tirkey and Neelam Lakra, value the financial assistance for its contribution to their families' well-being and independence.  The competition between the parties has resulted in increased financial assistance for women, ultimately benefiting those receiving it. 

This strategy, however, has been met with criticism from the BJP, who accuse the JMM of using these schemes as a political ploy. The BJP emphasizes its commitment to its Gogo Didi Yojana, promising its implementation should they come to power.  

Despite the political sparring, women in Jharkhand are clear about their priorities: tangible financial benefits that directly improve their lives. The upcoming election will determine which party's promises resonate most with this influential voting bloc.

title: Ladakh Protesters Return Home with Hope, but Fight for Rights Continues
news:
After nearly three weeks of camping outside the Ladakh Bhawan in Delhi, 150 protesters are returning home on Friday. The Ministry of Home Affairs has agreed to meet with them in December to discuss their demands. While the protesters are hopeful about the dialogue, they emphasize that the fight for their rights will continue.

The protesters, who walked from Ladakh to Delhi, are seeking the inclusion of the Union Territory in the Constitution's Sixth Schedule. This would grant Ladakh a degree of autonomy, allowing them to control their natural resources and create their own laws.  

Many protesters are also concerned about the lack of employment opportunities and the impact of climate change on the region. They argue that the absence of a Legislative Assembly since the removal of Article 370 has left them without adequate representation and a voice in crucial decisions.

While they are returning home with renewed hope, the protesters remain determined to continue advocating for their rights and ensuring that Ladakh's unique needs are addressed by the government.

title: Film Producer's Land Grab Case Takes Curious Turns
news:
The re-arrest of film producer B. Sivaramakrishna by Osmania University police in Hyderabad has raised eyebrows due to its unusual circumstances. 

Sivaramakrishna was initially arrested on October 17th, along with two others, for allegedly attempting to grab government land valued at thousands of crores. He secured conditional bail two days later. However, the police filed a petition on Monday alleging he had violated bail conditions, leading to the cancellation of his bail and subsequent re-arrest.

The main accusation against the producer is his attempt to seize 80 acres of land in Rayadurg and 10 acres in Yacharam, both located on the outskirts of Hyderabad. 

The police initially invoked sections related to cheating and forgery, but curiously omitted Section 467 (forgery) from the charges, despite the alleged crime revolving around forged documents. The police have explained that Section 468, which covers forgery for the purpose of cheating, was invoked instead. 

Legal experts have suggested that the accused remain in prison until the trial concludes, given the substantial value of the land involved.

A coincidental transfer of the magistrate who granted bail to the film producer added another layer of intrigue to the ongoing case.

title: Chennai Imposes ₹5,000 Fine on Bulk Waste Generators for Violating Solid Waste Management Rules
news:
The Greater Chennai Corporation (GCC) has announced a ₹5,000 fine for bulk waste generators who fail to comply with its solid waste management rules. These rules, enacted in 2019, classify establishments generating over 100 kg of waste daily as bulk waste generators. This includes, but is not limited to, government buildings, institutions, private organizations, hospitals, educational institutions, hotels, markets, and places of worship. 

The regulations mandate that Resident Welfare Associations and market associations occupying over 5,000 sq ft and generating more than 100 kg of waste per day must segregate biodegradable and non-biodegradable waste at the source. Biodegradable waste must be treated onsite through composting or bio-methanation, while recyclable waste should be handed over to GCC-authorized garbage collectors. 

The GCC has implemented 300 point-of-sale (POS) machines across 15 zones to collect fines. Between October 10th and 24th, a total of ₹25,73,800 was collected, with Zone 5 recording the highest number of transactions. 

GCC Commissioner J. Kumaragurubaran stated that the primary objective of these measures is to maintain city cleanliness and discourage public waste disposal. The corporation has partnered with Indian Overseas Bank to utilize POS machines instead of traditional challans.

title: Former District Registrar and Wife Convicted in Disproportionate Assets Case
news:
A former District Registrar in Chennai, Chandrasekaran, and his wife were sentenced to four years imprisonment and fined ₹1 lakh each by a special court in Chennai. The conviction stemmed from a disproportionate assets case filed by the Directorate of Vigilance and Anti-Corruption (DVAC). 

The DVAC investigation revealed that Chandrasekaran had accumulated assets worth ₹20,02,542.59 during his tenure as District Registrar, audit, Chennai South Registration Department, from 1991 to 2000. These assets were deemed disproportionate to his known income sources.  

The court also ordered Chandrasekaran's son, Vishnu Chakravarthy, who was a juvenile during the investigation period, to be transferred to the Juvenile Justice Board to face charges of abetting the crime.

title: Indian Dairy Farmers' Voice Heard at World Dairy Summit in Paris
news:
K.S. Mani, chairman of Milma and director of the National Cooperative Dairy Federation of India (NCDFI), represented Indian dairy farmers at the World Dairy Summit in Paris from October 15th to 18th. The summit, organized by the International Dairy Federation (IDF), focused on addressing global challenges facing the dairy sector, including climate change, rising input costs, and resource depletion. 

Mr. Mani emphasized India's immense export potential for value-added dairy products, highlighting opportunities for growth despite challenges like climate change. He advocated for leveraging government initiatives like the Dairy processing and Infrastructure Development Fund (DIDF) to boost exports, particularly to Southeast Asia, the Middle East, and Latin America.

The summit also addressed labor shortages, technology solutions, and sustainability. Mr. Mani acknowledged the importance of attracting younger farmers and skilled workers while noting India's unique situation with its vast network of smallholder farmers who are already adopting automation and digital tools. He highlighted the sustainability of India's cattle feeding system, which utilizes agricultural residues, promoting resource efficiency and waste reduction. 

With his experience as a farmer, entrepreneur, and cooperator, Mr. Mani's participation at the World Dairy Summit ensured that the voice of Indian dairy farmers was heard on the global stage.

title: Buses in Kozhikode Defy Court Order, Putting Passengers at Risk
news:
Despite a Kerala High Court order mandating closed doors on all moving buses, numerous private bus operators in Kozhikode district continue to ignore the rule. This disregard for passenger safety stems from the widespread malfunctioning of pneumatic doors, often due to a lack of regular maintenance.

While some buses have installed pneumatic doors, many are inoperable, creating hazards during boarding and alighting. Drivers also struggle with these faulty systems, particularly during peak traffic hours, when passengers often resort to standing on the footboard. 

A retired Motor Vehicles Department (MVD) officer attributes the issue to operators' reluctance to invest in regular servicing of the doors. The officer also points out that passengers are dissatisfied with the unprofessional and unsafe operation of the doors.

Recent accidents involving passengers being thrown from buses without doors during sudden stops or high-speed travel have failed to trigger significant changes in the operation of these buses. The elderly and students are particularly vulnerable to this negligence. Additionally, incidents of passengers getting pinched by malfunctioning doors have led some operators to simply run buses with open doors.

The decline in bus revenue has also contributed to the problem, making it less appealing for operators to employ door attendants full-time. This, coupled with the frequent unavailability of the passenger-operated door option on many buses, further escalates safety concerns.

In response to the rising complaints, MVD officers and road safety squads are increasing their efforts. Flash inspections on both city and rural routes are being conducted to crack down on "open-door trips" and other safety violations. A week-long special checking drive involving various enforcement squads is also being considered.

title: Kerala Couple Acquitted in 2012 Murder Case
news:
A Kerala woman and her friend were acquitted of murder charges by the High Court due to lack of evidence. The case involved the 2012 death of Mohandas, the woman's husband, who worked for a Malayalam daily.

The trial court had initially sentenced the duo to life imprisonment, but they appealed the decision. The High Court determined that the prosecution failed to directly link the pair to the murder. Much of the evidence presented was deemed circumstantial, leading to their acquittal.

title: Telangana's SHE Teams Celebrate 10 Years of Protecting Women
news:
Telangana's SHE Teams, a dedicated initiative combating harassment against women, marked their 10th anniversary on October 24th. Since their launch in 2014, the teams have significantly contributed to women's safety across the state, both in public and online spaces. 

The SHE Teams have handled over 66,000 petitions and registered over 6,000 FIRs in the last decade. They have also counselled over 15,000 individuals, registered over 17,000 petty cases, and warned over 16,000 minors under parental supervision. 

In addition to traditional methods, the teams have implemented innovative approaches like a dedicated mobile application, a state-wide WhatsApp number, and QR code complaint mechanisms, successfully addressing a range of issues from mobile harassment to eve-teasing.

DG of the Women Safety Wing, Shikha Goel, expressed pride in the SHE Teams' impact, emphasizing their ability to empower women across even the most remote areas of Telangana, ensuring they feel safe and supported.

title: 20-Year-Old Dies a Week After Road Accident in Hyderabad
news:
A 20-year-old electrician, Boya Srinivas, succumbed to injuries on Wednesday, October 24, a week after a road accident near Gachibowli, Hyderabad. 

Srinivas, a resident of Gulmohar Park Colony in Serilingampally, was returning from a friend's birthday party on the night of October 16 when the auto he was travelling in collided with a goods carrier in the early hours of October 17.  He sustained critical injuries and was initially admitted to a private hospital in Kondapur before being transferred to Osmania General Hospital, where he died during treatment.

The Chandanagar police have registered a case against the auto driver, Srinath, who was also a friend of the deceased.

title: Police Commissioner Congratulates New APPSC Chairperson
news:
Vijayawada, India - NTR Police Commissioner S.V. Rajashekar Babu met with A.R. Anuradha, the newly appointed Chairperson of the Andhra Pradesh Public Service Commission (APPSC), in Vijayawada on Thursday.  

Ms. Anuradha, a retired Director-General of Police, was appointed to the position just days prior.  Commissioner Babu expressed his congratulations to the new Chairperson on her appointment.

title: Pali Gains Classical Language Status: A Celebration of Buddhist Heritage
news:
The Indian Council for Cultural Relations (ICCR) hosted a conference in Colombo, Sri Lanka, bringing together Buddhist scholars and monks from Sri Lanka, Nepal, Myanmar, and Bangladesh. The event focused on the recent conferment of classical language status on Pali by the Indian government.

Participants highlighted the profound significance of Pali in preserving the "Dhamma" and fostering Buddhist practices. The scholars praised the Indian government's decision, seeing it as a testament to India's commitment to preserving and propagating Buddhist heritage and culture. 

Prime Minister Narendra Modi, expressing his gratitude on X, stated that the decision has generated a sense of joy among Buddhists worldwide. 

Pali, the language of the Buddhist Pali Canon (Tipiṭaka), holds immense importance for Theravada Buddhism. It is studied primarily to access Buddhist scriptures and is frequently used in ritual contexts. While the language is widely studied in Southeast Asian nations such as Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Thailand, Laos, and Cambodia, this new recognition from India strengthens its place within the global Buddhist community.

title: Japanese Diplomat and Industrialists Meet with Tamil Nadu Deputy Chief Minister
news:
Chennai, India - On Thursday, October 24th,  Deputy Chief Minister Udhayanidhi Stalin met with Japanese Consul-General in Chennai, Takahashi Muneo, along with prominent Indian industrialists. 

The meeting included Venu Srinivasan, chairman emeritus of TVS Motor Company, Mallika Srinivasan, chairperson and managing director of Tractors and Farm Equipment Limited, and Nandhini Rangaswamy, chairperson of CII’s Southern Region. Also present were Srivats Ram, CII Tamil Nadu Chairman, and A.R. Unnikrishnan, vice-chairman.

While the specific content of the meeting was not disclosed, it is likely the discussion focused on strengthening economic ties between Tamil Nadu and Japan, particularly in the areas of automotive, agriculture, and industry.

title: Rani Rampal Retires After Historic Hockey Career
news:
Indian women's hockey legend Rani Rampal has announced her retirement from the sport after a distinguished 16-year career. The announcement came during a ceremony held at the Major Dhyan Chand National Stadium in New Delhi, where she reflected on her career's highlights.

Rampal, who captained the Indian team to their historic fourth-place finish at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, cited the quarterfinal victory over Australia as her most cherished memory. She expressed her gratitude for the opportunity to retire at the stadium named after the legendary Major Dhyan Chand, where she last played in 2012 during Olympic qualifiers.

The former captain's impact on Indian hockey is undeniable. Over her career, she played over 250 matches and scored over 100 goals, leading the team to numerous victories.  She was instrumental in securing India's silver medals at the 2017 Women's Asian Cup and the 2018 Asian Games, serving as India's flag-bearer during the closing ceremony of the latter.

In recognition of her contributions, Hockey India honored her by retiring her iconic jersey number 28. While she expressed her emotions at ending this chapter of her career, she emphasized the beginning of a new one.

title: Bengaluru Gets Immersed in Kafka's 'The Trial' with 'I, Josef' Binaural Audio Show
news:
Bangalore's theatre scene is getting a unique experience with 'I, Josef', a binaural audio show that plunges audiences into the unsettling world of Franz Kafka's "The Trial". Directed and designed by Gaurav Singh Nijjer and written by Varoon P Anand, the show doesn't just showcase the story, it aims to **pull audiences into Josef K's nightmare**.

Using binaural audio technology, 'I, Josef' creates a **3D soundscape** that envelops the listener, making them feel like they're experiencing the story first-hand.  This innovative approach allows the audience to truly **immerse themselves in the confusion and alienation** that Josef K faces, experiencing the world through his eyes. 

The show incorporates **multimedia elements like projections and lighting**, further enhancing the immersive experience and making it a powerful reflection of Kafka's timeless themes – alienation, bureaucratic absurdity, and existential dread.  

'I, Josef' is more than a simple adaptation; it's a **commentary on the modern world** where surveillance, impersonal bureaucracy, and feelings of being lost in systems are prevalent. 

Commissioned by the Goethe Institut New Delhi as part of #100yearskafka, the show premiered in September 2024 and is currently available in English and German, with a Hindi version planned for 2025.  Catch 'I, Josef' on October 26 and 27 at the Prestige Centre for Performing Arts. For more information, visit kaivalyaplays.org/i-josef.

title: Jharkhand Election Heats Up: Soren Family Files Nominations, BJP Leaders Face Attacks
news:
The Jharkhand Assembly elections are underway, with the Soren family, at the heart of the political battle, filing their nomination papers. Chief Minister Hemant Soren is contesting from Barhait, his wife Kalpana from Gandey, and brother Basant from Dumka. 

The election campaign has seen heated rhetoric with Hemant Soren labeling BJP leaders from other states as "migratory people" who will "vanish" after the elections. He believes these leaders are merely campaigning in Jharkhand for political gain and will leave after the results are announced. 

The BJP has retaliated with strong criticism, comparing the ruling coalition of JMM, Congress, and RJD to a "cyclone." Union Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan, in charge of the BJP campaign in Jharkhand, asserted that the coalition is more dangerous than Cyclone Dana. 

Furthermore, the financial wealth of the Soren family is coming under scrutiny. According to the affidavit, Kalpana Soren is richer than Hemant Soren, with her assets significantly increasing over the past five years. 

With the first phase of polling scheduled for November 13th and the second phase on November 20th, the Jharkhand Assembly elections are expected to be closely contested.  The focus will be on the Soren family's ability to retain power against the BJP's challenge.

title: Mosque Protest in Uttarkashi Turns Violent, Over 30 Injured
news:
A protest demanding the demolition of a mosque in Uttarkashi, Uttarakhand, turned violent on Thursday, leaving five police personnel and over 30 protesters injured. The rally, organized by right-wing groups including the Sanyukt Sanatan Dharma Rakshak Dal, Bajrang Dal, and Devbhoomi Raksha Abhiyan, alleged that the mosque was illegally built on government land near the Kashi Vishwanath temple.

The protesters, who had obtained permission for the rally, attempted to break through police barricades, leading to a confrontation. Police responded with a lathi-charge to disperse the crowd after stones were thrown at them. 

Darshan Bharti, head of the Devbhoomi Raksha Abhiyan, claimed that the mosque was initially a small room that had expanded over time and alleged the land was illegally acquired from a Hindu family. However, Uttarkashi District Magistrate Meharban Singh Bisht had previously confirmed that the mosque possesses all necessary documents and is registered with the Waqf Board.

title: Delhi L-G's Testimony Contradicts Official Records on Tree Felling
news:
The Supreme Court of India has discovered a discrepancy in the testimony of Delhi's Lieutenant Governor (L-G) Vinai Kumar Saxena regarding his knowledge of illegal tree felling in the protected ridge area. 

Saxena, who is also the ex-officio Chairperson of the Delhi Development Authority (DDA), claimed in a personal affidavit that he was only informed about the tree felling on June 10th, through a letter from the DDA Vice-Chairperson. However, official records reveal that Saxena was informed about the "blunder of felling the trees" on April 12th.

This inconsistency led the Supreme Court to direct both the L-G and former DDA Vice-Chairperson Subhasish Panda, who was in office during the tree felling incident, to file affidavits explaining the discrepancy. They are also required to disclose the date on which they first obtained knowledge of the tree felling.

The court has requested the original records related to the incident to be submitted for review. The case has been adjourned until Tuesday. 

This investigation stems from a petition filed in the Supreme Court alleging that the trees were felled on Saxena's orders after a site visit on February 3rd. The L-G has denied any involvement in the illegal felling, stating he visited the site on his way back from the Central Armed Police Forces Institute of Medical Sciences (CAPFIMS) Hospital and was not informed that felling the trees required Supreme Court permission.

title: Maharashtra Polls: Mahayuti Strategizes to Avoid Rebel Candidates
news:
Ahead of the Maharashtra assembly elections, the Mahayuti alliance, consisting of the BJP, Shiv Sena (Shinde faction), and Ajit Pawar's NCP, has finalized its seat allocation strategy. To minimize the risk of rebel candidates disrupting their campaign, the alliance has decided to withhold the names of candidates for eight seats in the Mumbai metropolitan area until the last minute.  

Union Home Minister Amit Shah held a four-hour meeting with alliance leaders, including Maharashtra Chief Minister Eknath Shinde, Deputy Chief Minister Devendra Fadnavis, and Ajit Pawar, to strategize on seat allocation and campaign strategy. 

The alliance is facing a multi-pronged challenge with the presence of two Shiv Sena factions, two NCP factions, the Congress, the BJP, the Maharashtra Navnirman Sena, and the Vanchit Bahujan Aghadi. To counter potential rebel candidates, the Mahayuti has chosen to delay candidate announcements for key Mumbai seats, including Andheri East, Lokhandwala, Bhayandar, Ghatkopar East, and Borivili.

The overall seat distribution remains unchanged, with the BJP contesting 150-155 seats, the Shiv Sena (Shinde) contesting 80-90 seats, and the rest being contested by Ajit Pawar's NCP. 

The alliance is also focusing on Prime Minister Narendra Modi's campaign strategy. At least 12 public rallies by the Prime Minister are planned across Maharashtra, recognizing his immense popularity in the state. 

The Maharashtra assembly elections are scheduled for November 20, with the results to be announced on November 23.

title: ISRO Satellites Monitor Cyclone Dana
news:
The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) has been tracking Cyclone Dana since October 20 using its polar orbiting satellite EOS-06 and geostationary satellite INSAT-3DR.  

ISRO's satellites are providing valuable information about the cyclone's status, including ocean wind patterns and circulation, which helps in better monitoring and mitigation of the cyclone threat. The agency has released pictures and videos of the storm, highlighting the crucial role of satellite data in disaster preparedness and response. 

Cyclone Dana is expected to make landfall near the Odisha-West Bengal coast on October 24, potentially impacting the Kolkata area.

title: Kochi Hosts Exhibition Showcasing the Works of Renowned Artist Achuthan Kudallur
news:
Kochi's Durbar Hall Art Gallery is currently hosting "The Memory of Colour", an exhibition showcasing the works of renowned artist Achuthan Kudallur. The exhibition features approximately 70 paintings, old photographs, and archival materials, offering a glimpse into the artist's prolific career. 

The exhibition was inaugurated by film historian and wildlife conservationist Theodore Bhaskaran, who highlighted Kudallur's unique approach to abstract art. Unlike many artists who draw inspiration from the external world, Kudallur's abstract works stemmed from his internal world, influenced by his love for literature, particularly Albert Camus' "The Rebel" and Nikos Kazantzakis' "Zorba The Greek".  

The exhibition, organized in collaboration with Ashvita's, Chennai, will be open to the public from 11 am to 7 pm daily until November 11th.

Achuthan Kudallur, born in Kudallur, Ponnani, studied engineering before moving to Madras, where he became a member of the Madras Arts Club.  His artistic endeavors earned him recognition internationally, and his works are considered significant contributions to the world of art.  Sadly, he passed away in 2022.

title: Journalist's Phone Not Listed in Seizure Memo:  Bail Hearing for Mahesh Langa Continues
news:
**Ahmedabad, India (October 24, 2024)** - A city court in Ahmedabad on Thursday reserved judgment on the bail application of Mahesh Langa, a correspondent for The Hindu, who was arrested on October 8 in connection with an alleged GST scam. The court is expected to deliver its verdict on Friday.

Langa's legal team highlighted a discrepancy in the police's seizure memo, which does not list the journalist's phone among the recovered items.  Vedanta Rajguru, Langa's counsel, pointed out that the memo mentions two laptops, a desktop, an iPhone, a pen drive, tax returns, documents, ₹1.8 lakh, a phone directory, and a book manuscript, but not the phone. The police also claimed to have recovered ₹20 lakh from Langa's home, which is also not mentioned in the memo.

While the police did not respond to these points in court, they indicated that the ₹20 lakh was recorded orally during a "panchnama," a police procedure for recording an incident.

The police have also filed a separate case against Langa, based on a complaint by the Gujarat Maritime Board (GMB), accusing him of theft, criminal conspiracy, cheating, and corruption. The GMB alleges that Langa leaked confidential documents, in connivance with GMB staff.  The police are investigating whether these documents were part of the items seized by the Ahmedabad Crime Branch, but they are not mentioned in the seizure memo.

Langa's arrest stems from a GST scam investigation involving Dhruvi Enterprise, a company accused of creating fake firms to claim fraudulent tax credits.  Manoj Langa, a relative of Mahesh Langa, owns DA Enterprise, which is mentioned in the FIR.  The arrest of Mahesh Langa is based on Manoj's statement. 

The case continues to unfold, with the court's decision on Langa's bail application expected on Friday.

title: Madras High Court Dismisses Plea to Fill Vacancies in Ramanathaswamy Temple
news:
The Madurai Bench of the Madras High Court has dismissed a petition seeking the immediate filling of staff vacancies at the Ramanathaswamy Temple in Rameswaram, Tamil Nadu. The petition argued that the vacancies constituted a serious deficiency in service for the temple, which attracts thousands of pilgrims daily.

The court's decision stems from an interpretation of a Supreme Court order regarding the appointment of Archakas (priests) in Tamil Nadu's agamic temples. The Commissioner of the Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Department, in an affidavit, stated that the Supreme Court order implied a freeze on such appointments.

While the court acknowledged that this interpretation might not be entirely just, it refrained from expressing an opinion due to it being an interpretation of a higher court's order. 

The court dismissed the petition, but left it open for the petitioner to approach the Supreme Court for clarification on the matter.

title: Telangana Police Collaborate with Maharashtra and Chhattisgarh Ahead of State Elections
news:
Police officers from Telangana, Maharashtra, and Chhattisgarh met in Gadchiroli, Maharashtra, on Thursday to discuss security measures ahead of the upcoming Maharashtra Assembly elections in November.  The meeting focused on strengthening security in Maoist-affected areas along the shared border, ensuring a safe and smooth electoral process.

The meeting was attended by officers from Telangana's Mancherial, Jayashankar Bhupalpally, and Kumram Bheem Asifabad districts, led by Ramagundam Police Commissioner M. Srinivas. Senior CRPF officials and police officers from the border districts of Maharashtra and Chhattisgarh also participated.

Key discussion points included intelligence sharing, enhanced vigilance at border checkpoints, and joint security arrangements to counter any potential threats during the elections. The meeting highlights the collaborative approach taken by these states to ensure a secure environment during the critical electoral period.

title: NIA Arrests Arsh Dalla Associate at Delhi Airport
news:
The National Investigation Agency (NIA) has apprehended Baljeet Singh alias Baljeet Maur, an alleged associate of designated terrorist Arshdeep Singh alias Arsh Dalla, at Delhi's Indira Gandhi International Airport. Maur, a resident of Bathinda district, Punjab, was apprehended upon his arrival from the United Arab Emirates. He is wanted in several cases, including a Khalistan Terrorist Force (KTF) related case registered by the NIA earlier this year.

Maur, who was subject to a Look-Out Circular issued in February 2024 and a non-bailable warrant of arrest since June 2024, is suspected of providing logistical support, identifying targets for extortion, recruiting new associates, and facilitating terror funding for Dalla's India-based network. 

The NIA investigation indicates Maur was a key conspirator in the KTF's alleged plot to instigate terror in Punjab. The KTF is accused of engaging in extortion, recruitment, targeted killings, and smuggling arms and ammunition into India. Maur's arrest marks a significant step in the ongoing fight against terrorism in India, particularly concerning the activities of the KTF and Arsh Dalla.

title: ITC Q2 Earnings: Profit Up Despite Challenges
news:
ITC Limited reported a solid performance in the second quarter of FY25, with net profit increasing by 3.1% year-on-year to Rs 5,078.3 crore. Revenue jumped 16.8% to Rs 19,327.8 crore, driven by strong growth in agri business and hotels.

Despite a challenging operating environment marked by subdued demand, heavy rains, high food inflation, and rising input costs, ITC demonstrated resilience.  The company also highlighted increased competition in certain categories, including noodles, snacks, biscuits, and soaps.

Notably, ITC's cigarettes business recorded a 7.3% YoY increase in net segment revenue, while hotels delivered strong performance, with revenue up 12.1% YoY. The agri business segment also saw impressive growth, with revenue up 47% YoY.

The company's board of directors approved the acquisition of shares in EIH Limited and HLV Limited from Russell Credit Limited, consolidating ITC's shareholding in these companies. They also approved the acquisition of the entire share capital of Greenacre Holdings Limited.

title: Wives of Telangana Special Police Constables Protest Long Working Hours
news:
Wives of constables from the 17th Battalion of the Telangana Special Police (TGSP) in Sardapur, Rajanna Sircilla district, staged a protest in Sircilla town on Thursday, demanding a reduction in their husbands' long working hours. They claim that their husbands are constantly engaged in "arduous work," leaving them with little time for their families and children.

The women, some carrying their babies, sat on the main road at Ambedkar Chowrasta, calling for the government to implement weekly offs and other welfare initiatives similar to those in neighboring states. They also advocated for the implementation of a "One State, One Police" system to ensure uniform working hours and service conditions for both civil and special police personnel.

The protest was eventually intervened by local police, who shifted the women to the 17th Battalion headquarters. They were reportedly assured that their grievances would be brought to the attention of higher authorities.

title: Domain Name Standoff: Student Demands ₹1 Crore From Reliance for JioHotstar.com
news:
A Delhi-based app developer has secured the domain name JioHotstar.com, capitalizing on the anticipated merger of JioCinema and Hotstar. Now, he's demanding ₹1 crore from Reliance Industries to fund his MBA at Cambridge University.

The developer, who wishes to remain anonymous, claims he foresaw the merger last September and registered the domain for a small sum. After receiving no response from Reliance following emails to senior executives, he went public, demanding the large sum. Reliance has reportedly offered only a refund of registration costs and threatened legal action. 

The developer, a middle-class entrepreneur with a background in film recommendation algorithms, believes his asking price is reasonable considering Reliance's vast resources. He has faced hacking attempts and security concerns, and while legal experts have offered to help him, he expresses reluctance to engage in a legal battle against the Ambanis.

title: Bihar's Prohibition Policy Sparks Political Feud
news:
The ongoing political battle in Bihar between the ruling Janata Dal (United) (JD(U)) and the opposition Rashtriya Janata Dal (RJD) has intensified, fueled by the issue of prohibition and recent hooch deaths. 

The RJD, in a post on X, accused the JD(U) of facilitating "unlimited availability of liquor" in the state, despite the prohibition law. This follows a series of deaths from consuming spurious liquor earlier this year. The RJD blamed Chief Minister Nitish Kumar and his party for the deaths. 

In response, the JD(U) called the RJD the "Rashtriya Jahrila Party" (poisonous party), criticizing their past records and accusing them of fostering division and crime. 

The political war of words comes as the leader of the opposition, Tejashwi Yadav, has also blamed the government for the liquor availability, alleging a nexus between politicians, police, and mafia. 

Despite the state being declared dry in 2016, over 150 deaths have been recorded due to hooch tragedies, with over 10,000 liters of liquor seized daily in 2023. The issue has become a key point of contention in the state's political landscape.

title: Kerala Institutions Honored for Scientific Sanitation Practices
news:
Kozhikode, Kerala - The Kozhikode District Collector, Snehil Kumar Singh, has awarded certificates of appreciation to institutions recognized for their exemplary scientific sanitation management practices.  Providence Women’s College, MVR Cancer Centre, and CRC Kerala were acknowledged for their outstanding efforts in establishing green campuses. 

These institutions are recognized for their commitment to sustainable practices. They adhere to green protocols, ensure proper segregation of non-biodegradable waste, and effectively convert food waste into compost and biogas.

title: St. Joseph's College Library Wins Prestigious SSMB Award
news:
The newly renovated library building of St. Joseph's College, Devagiri, in Kozhikode, Kerala has been recognized for its exceptional design and construction.  The facility, spanning 42,000 square feet, has been awarded the 2024 Steel Structural and Metal Building (SSMB) Award by the Indian Steel Construction Association (ISCA).  This prestigious accolade, awarded in the category of best commercial building (steel construction) in India, highlights the building's outstanding achievements in design, engineering, and construction. 

The award was presented by Anveet Singh, president of the ISCA, at an event held in Mumbai on October 23rd. The award is a testament to the college's commitment to providing a modern and functional learning environment for its students.

title: Government Doctors Demand Staffing Boost and Pay Review in Tamil Nadu
news:
The Service Doctors and Post Graduates Association (SDPGA) in Tamil Nadu has raised concerns about a severe shortage of healthcare professionals in the state.  The association  urges the government to swiftly fill nearly 4,000 vacant doctor positions out of a total of 20,000 sanctioned posts.  

The SDPGA highlights that based on Indian Public Health Standards (IPHS), the state needs around 30,000 doctors to meet the current patient load and hospital bed capacity.  The shortage extends beyond doctors, affecting nurses, paramedics, and other hospital staff.

In addition to filling vacancies, the association calls for increasing the number of doctor and healthcare worker positions in line with National Medical Commission and IPHS standards. They also demand the government address a long-standing issue concerning pay and promotions for government doctors by reviewing Government Order 354. 

The SDPGA also emphasizes the importance of increasing the number of Comprehensive Emergency Obstetric and Newborn Care centers staffed by specialists to reduce maternal mortality rates.  They advocate for abolishing 24-hour shifts for doctors and suggest that the premium paid for the Chief Minister’s Comprehensive Health Insurance Scheme be allocated directly to the Health department for quality care.

title: Andhra Pradesh Sees 11.8% Dip in MGNREGA Job Generation
news:
Andhra Pradesh witnessed a significant decline in job generation under the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA) during the April-September period of the current financial year.  A report by LibTech India revealed an 11.8% drop in person-days compared to the same period last year, mirroring a nationwide trend of 16% reduction. 

While Andhra Pradesh started strong, generating the highest number of person-days in the country in April 2024, momentum was disrupted by compliance concerns raised by the central government. This led to a noticeable reduction in employment opportunities.

The report highlights a sharp decline in specific districts such as Nellore (35.1% decrease), Kurnool (30.9% decrease), and Tirupati (22.4% decrease). However, some districts, including Parvathipuram Manyam, Sri Sathya Sai, and Alluri Sitharama Raju, bucked the trend by showing an increase in person-days.

A caste-wise analysis revealed disparities in employment opportunities. Scheduled Castes and "Others" experienced significant declines, while Scheduled Tribes saw a slight improvement. This suggests that targeted interventions may have been effective for certain groups. 

To address the declining trend and ensure the long-term sustainability of MGNREGA in Andhra Pradesh, the report recommends closer collaboration between the state and central governments. This partnership would help address compliance issues and provide support to struggling districts, ultimately revitalizing employment opportunities and securing the program's success.

title: Madras High Court Hears Appeal in SpiceJet TDS Dispute
news:
The Madras High Court on Thursday commenced the final hearing of an appeal by the Indian government against a ruling in favor of former SpiceJet Chairman Kalanithi Maran. The case revolves around a dispute concerning alleged non-remittance of Tax Deducted at Source (TDS) by the airline.

The government, represented by Additional Solicitor-General R. Sankaranarayanan, appealed a 2018 ruling by Justice M. Duraiswamy, who had dismissed proceedings that declared Mr. Maran the ‘principal officer’ of SpiceJet and therefore liable for the non-remittance. 

Justice Duraiswamy had ruled that Mr. Maran, as a non-executive chairman, could not be held responsible for the airline’s day-to-day operations. The court also acknowledged that SpiceJet had subsequently paid the full TDS amount. 

However, the government maintains that the Madras High Court lacked jurisdiction to handle the case, as Mr. Maran had also filed a petition against similar charges in the Delhi High Court.  

The hearing will continue on Monday, with arguments expected from Mr. Maran’s legal counsel.

title: BJP Wins Dakshina Kannada By-Election,  MLC-Elect Credits Party Workers
news:
Kishore B.R., the newly elected BJP member of the Legislative Council from Dakshina Kannada, attributes his victory to the hard work of all BJP party workers.  He highlighted the collaborative efforts of the party and stated his commitment to strengthening the panchayat raj system, citing his own rural background and understanding of people's challenges.

BJP National President J.P. Nadda expressed pride in the victory, viewing it as a testament to the party's commitment to grassroots leadership and social justice for OBC communities. Nadda criticized the Congress for its alleged exploitation of the OBC community and its minority appeasement politics. 

B.Y. Vijayendra, State President of the BJP, characterized the victory as a "gift" from voters reflecting dissatisfaction with the Congress administration. He emphasized the strength of the BJP in Dakshina Kannada and Udupi districts, citing the win as a morale boost for upcoming by-elections.

title: Former Idukki DMO Granted Bail in Bribery Case
news:
A former District Medical Officer (DMO) of Idukki, Manoj L., has been granted bail by the Kerala High Court. He had been arrested earlier this month by the Vigilance and Anti-Corruption Bureau (VACB) for allegedly accepting a ₹75,000 bribe from a hotel owner.

The prosecution alleged that Manoj demanded the bribe to cover up irregularities found at a resort in Chithirapuram, Idukki, following an inspection. He allegedly demanded ₹1 lakh, which was reduced to ₹75,000, and instructed the owner to send the money through Google Pay to the account of his friend's driver. 

The court, while granting bail, emphasized that the primary purpose of bail is to facilitate investigations. It also stated that denying bail is not justifiable if investigations are not hindered. The VACB is currently investigating another similar complaint against Manoj from a hotel owner in Munnar.

title: Sattankulam Case Trial Extended by Four Months
news:
The Madurai Bench of the Madras High Court has granted a four-month extension to the First Additional District and Sessions Court in Madurai to complete the trial in the case of P. Jayaraj and his son J. Benicks. The two men died in police custody in Sattankulam in 2020, allegedly after being attacked. 

The High Court initially ordered the trial to be completed within six months in March 2021, following a petition filed by Selvarani, Jayaraj's wife. The court has now granted multiple extensions to the trial court to complete the proceedings.

title: UDF, LDF Candidates File Nominations in Palakkad By-Election
news:
The Palakkad Assembly by-election is set to be a closely contested race, with both the United Democratic Front (UDF) and the Left Democratic Front (LDF) candidates filing their nominations on Thursday, October 24th. 

Rahul Mamkootathil, the UDF candidate, filed his nomination after visiting temples in the district and was accompanied by his mother and sister. A large number of UDF supporters participated in a roadshow led by Mr. Mamkootathil, which included prominent leaders like Youth Congress national president Uday Bhanu Chib and several MPs and MLAs.

Meanwhile, LDF candidate P. Sarin filed his nomination in a procession from the CPI(M) district committee office. He was accompanied by several senior CPI(M) and CPI leaders, including central committee member A.K. Balan and state committee members N.N. Krishnadas and C.K. Rajendran. 

The BJP candidate, C. Krishnakumar, filed his nomination on Wednesday. The by-election is scheduled for November 13th.

title: Two Soldiers Injured in Militant Attack in Jammu and Kashmir's Baramulla
news:
On Thursday, two Indian Army personnel and two porters were injured in a firefight with militants in the Baramulla district of Jammu and Kashmir. The incident occurred near the Nagin post of Butapathri Sector, close to the Line of Control (LoC) and the tourist destination of Gulmarg. 

Initial reports suggest that an Army convoy came under fire from militants hiding in the surrounding forests.  The operation against the militants is ongoing. 

In a separate incident, a 19-year-old non-local worker, Shubam Kumar, was injured after being shot by suspected militants in Pulwama district. Kumar sustained a bullet injury to his hand and is currently in stable condition. Security forces have cordoned off the area but have yet to locate the attackers.

This marks the third attack on non-locals in the Kashmir valley in the past week. The recent surge in violence has raised significant security concerns and prompted a high-level meeting by the Jammu and Kashmir Lieutenant-Governor, Manoj Sinha.  The meeting focused on strategies to prevent further incidents. 

The attacks come amidst heightened tensions in the region and have triggered a security review of key infrastructure projects in Srinagar. While scores of non-local workers are leaving the valley due to the onset of winter, many are confident about staying back.

title: Yoga Guru Ramdev Inaugurates 51st All India Oriental Conference, Emphasizing Sanskrit's Growing Importance
news:
Udupi, India - Baba Ramdev, founder of Patanjali Yogapeeth, inaugurated the 51st session of the All India Oriental Conference on October 24th. The conference, jointly organized by Paryaya Puthige Mutt, Bharatiya Vidvat Parishad, and Central Sanskrit University, New Delhi, took place at Sri Krishna Mutt. 

Ramdev stressed the increasing significance of Sanskrit and Sanatana dharma, stating that "The future belongs to Sanskrit and Sanatana dharma. The new era is of Bharat." He highlighted a shift in perspective, with those who once questioned the value of Sanskrit now advocating for its study. He attributed this to the language's unique prestige and its role as the root of many others. 

Paryaya Puthige Mutt Seer Sugunendra Tirtha Swami, presiding over the event, echoed Ramdev's sentiment on the importance of preserving Sanatana dharma. He emphasized "Prachya Vidya" (ancient knowledge) as the core of Indian wisdom, highlighting Sanskrit's enduring presence across time. 

The conference addressed the promotion and propagation of Sanskrit, ranging from grassroots to university levels, with Central government representatives and academic leaders emphasizing its significance. 

Ramdev was honored with the title "Yogendra Samrat" and Acharya Balkrishna received the title "Ayurveda Vidya Vibhuti" during the event.

title: Special Trains to Ease Passenger Rush Between Hubballi and Kollam
news:
To accommodate increased passenger demand, special trains will operate between Hubballi and Kollam via Madurai and Tenkasi.

title: BRS Demands Disqualification of Defected MLAs
news:
The Bharat Rashtra Samithi (BRS) has reiterated its call for the disqualification of 10 MLAs and 8 MLCs who left the party to join the ruling Congress. This demand comes in the wake of comments by Congress MLC and senior leader T. Jeevan Reddy expressing his difficulty in accepting the defections.

BRS MLA and former Legislative Affairs Minister V. Prashanth Reddy stated on Thursday that the Chief Minister A. Revanth Reddy, Assembly Speaker G. Prasad Kumar, and Council Chairman G. Sukender Reddy should take immediate action to disqualify the defectors. He accused the Congress government of undemocratic practices and the police of harassing those who question the government's decisions.

Prashanth Reddy also suggested that the defected MLAs face a fresh election, allowing voters to decide whether their actions were justified.

title: Kerala's 40 MW Thottiyar Hydroelectric Project to be Inaugurated on October 28
news:
The 40 MW Thottiyar hydroelectric project in Idukki, Kerala, is scheduled to be inaugurated by Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan on October 28th. The project, which has already generated 17 million units of electricity, is expected to produce 99 million units annually.

The project's two generators were synchronized with the power grid in July and September. The inauguration will coincide with the upcoming commissioning of the 60 MW Pallivasal Extension Scheme in Idukki. 

The Kerala government aims to increase the state's power generation capacity to 10,000 MW by 2030, and the Thottiyar project is a key step in this endeavor. The government is also focusing on completing the 24 MW Chinnar and 40 MW Mankulam hydroelectric projects as soon as possible.

title: Kerala PSUs Focus on Energy Efficiency
news:
A workshop on energy efficiency for Public Sector Units (PSUs) in Kerala was held on October 24th, 2024.  The workshop, organized by the Energy Management Centre – Kerala (EMC) and the Bureau of Public Enterprises, aimed to highlight the importance of energy efficiency within PSUs. 

Kerala's Electricity Minister, K. Krishnankutty, advocated for the establishment of solar power plants on unused land owned by PSUs.  He emphasized the need for these units to contribute to sustainable energy practices. 

The workshop discussed various aspects of energy efficiency, including financial assistance available for energy audits. Representatives from 88 PSUs attended the event, highlighting the widespread interest in implementing energy-saving measures.

title: Farmers Demand Higher Compensation for Belagavi Bypass Land Acquisition
news:
Farmers in Belagavi, Karnataka, are demanding increased compensation for their land acquired for the construction of the Halaga-Machhe Bypass. The bypass, part of the Belagavi Ring Road, is being built by the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI).

The Public Works Minister, Satish Jarkiholi, has assured the farmers that he will lead a delegation to the Union Minister for Roads, Transport and Highways, Nitin Gadkari, to seek a revised compensation amount. The delegation will present a memorandum requesting an increase in the current compensation, which has already been raised to ₹45 crore from the initial ₹15 crore.

Farmers have been protesting the land acquisition since 2011, arguing that the project will deprive them of fertile farmland, their primary source of livelihood. They have also sought realignment of the road. Despite legal challenges, the farmers have continued their opposition, leading to delays in construction.

The Minister's intervention comes as a response to the farmers' demands. The delegation is expected to meet Mr. Gadkari in New Delhi soon.

title: 11 Arrested for Assaulting Congress Activist in Byndoor
news:
On October 18, 2024, Srikant Poojary Hadavu, the president of the Byndoor Block Congress, and his friends were attacked near Mahavishnu Temple in Hadavu village, Byndoor taluk, Udupi district.  The Udupi police have apprehended 11 individuals allegedly involved in the assault, including Vishwanath Padukone. Additionally, two minors have been charged under the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection) Act. 

The attack involved a group of around 20 individuals wielding weapons. Poojary and his friends were assaulted, with one of the assailants even threatening Poojary with an unlicensed firearm. 

Police investigation revealed that the attack stemmed from a pre-existing rivalry between Poojary and the accused. The authorities have seized an unlicensed firearm and four two-wheelers from the arrested individuals.

title: Vijayawada Police Seek VMC's Help to Clear Road Obstructions
news:
Vijayawada traffic police are urging the Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) to remove encroachments hindering traffic flow in key areas. 

On Thursday, Additional Deputy Commissioner of Police (ADCP) A.V.L. Prasanna Kumar met with VMC Commissioner H.M. Dhyanachandra to discuss traffic problems in the city.  The police requested the VMC to clear pavements and roads in Governorpet, Krishnalanka, Gandhinagar, and Patamata. 

Further, the police have requested the VMC to widen the Ramavarappadu Ring Road and shift the road divider near Marg Krishnaiah Hotel to the NTR Circle. Additionally, they have asked for the VMC to allow left turns from Benz Circle to the Eluru Road service road, and to provide new cabins for traffic police at key intersections.

The VMC Commissioner has assured the police that he will visit the problem areas and take necessary action.

title: Periyar University Faces Backlash for Censorship of Professor's Books
news:

This comes after a similar memo last year sparked criticism. Subramani, a government nominee and syndicate member, authored the books "Macaulay was an Enemy of Conservative Education" and "Periyar's Battlefield".

The university claims these books constitute misconduct, citing a lack of permission from the vice-chancellor. However, Subramani's colleagues and the Periyar University Teachers’ Association (PUTA) argue that the notice is an act of revenge and undermines academic freedom.

The PUTA president, V. Vaithianathan, highlights that Subramani, as director of the Periyar Chair, has a legitimate right to write on Periyar E.V. Ramasamy. He also emphasizes that the books are essentially collections of newspaper articles, not requiring permission. 

The issue has sparked controversy, with PUTA condemning the university's actions as a means to suppress academic freedom. The Tamil Nadu government has been urged to intervene, while the university administration remains silent.

title: Thiruvananthapuram to Experience Water Supply Disruption on October 26
news:

A new transformer and control-relay panel will be installed, resulting in power supply cut-off to the KWA water treatment plants from 1 p.m. to 5 p.m.  This interruption will halt pumping operations, impacting water distribution to the city.

All areas under the Thiruvananthapuram Corporation will be affected by the disruption.  High-line areas are expected to experience restored supply only by Sunday night.

title: Diwali Bonus and DA Hike for State Employees in Uttar Pradesh and Arunachal Pradesh
news:
Both Uttar Pradesh and Arunachal Pradesh have announced a 3% Dearness Allowance (DA) hike for their state government employees, effective from July 1, 2024. This brings the total DA to 53% in both states. 

The Uttar Pradesh government has also announced a Diwali bonus for its non-gazetted employees, equal to one month's salary capped at Rs 7,000. This bonus will be paid along with the October salary. 

The DA hike in Arunachal Pradesh will benefit over 68,818 state employees, including pensioners and All India Service officers stationed in the state. 

The DA is a government-provided adjustment that helps employees and pensioners cope with the impact of inflation on their purchasing power. It is calculated as a percentage of the basic salary and is based on the Consumer Price Index (CPI). 

These recent announcements follow similar DA hikes in other states, including Chhattisgarh, Odisha, Himachal Pradesh, Sikkim, and Jharkhand.

title: Male Superintendents in Women's Prisons: Madras High Court Seeks State Response
news:
The Madras High Court has demanded a response from the Tamil Nadu government regarding the appointment of male Superintendents at women's special prisons in Vellore, Coimbatore, Salem, and Madurai. The petition highlights the lack of a Deputy Inspector General of Prisons (Women Prisoners) in the state for the past 10 years, despite the position's creation in 2009. The court, comprising Chief Justice K.R. Shriram and Justice Senthilkumar Ramamoorthy, has directed the State Government Pleader to respond within two weeks.
